content:
When defining the elementary stochastic integral Vâˆ™XV \bullet XVâˆ™X (Def. 10.9), a continuous R\mathbb{R}R-bilinear map B:Eâ†’Fâ†’GB : E \to F \to GB:Eâ†’Fâ†’G was proposed in the blueprint where FFF is the codomain of the simple process VVV, EEE is the codomain of the stochastic process XXX, and GGG is the codomain of the resulting process. Here we assume the more general case than the specific case of scalar multiplication B(x,r)=râ‹…xB(x, r) = r \cdot xB(x,r)=râ‹…x and E=GE = GE=G. I am roughly aware this is in line with some things that we want to do with vector integral. However, I am not sure how much more general this is. We require the following properties of BBB and FFF:

  • BBB is linear in both arguments.

  • Lemma 10.11, in the most general case, would be something like: XXX is EEE-valued, WWW is FFF-valued, and B1:Eâ†’Fâ†’GB_1 : E \to F \to GB1â€‹:Eâ†’Fâ†’G so Wâˆ™XW \bullet XWâˆ™X is GGG-valued. Then if VVV is HHH-valued, and there is B2:Gâ†’Hâ†’IB_2 : G \to H \to IB2â€‹:Gâ†’Hâ†’I, the final Vâˆ™(Wâˆ™X)V \bullet (W \bullet X)Vâˆ™(Wâˆ™X) is III-valued. Then we need a â€œmultiplicationâ€ C:Hâ†’Fâ†’JC : H \to F \to JC:Hâ†’Fâ†’J, another B3:Eâ†’Jâ†’IB_3 : E \to J \to IB3â€‹:Eâ†’Jâ†’I, and a condition B2(B1(x,w),v)=B3(x,C(v,w))B_2(B_1(x, w), v) = B_3(x, C(v, w))B2â€‹(B1â€‹(x,w),v)=B3â€‹(x,C(v,w)). I think this is too complicated. For example, if we simply require that B1=B2B_1 = B_2B1â€‹=B2â€‹, then to make things type-check we already have E=G=IE=G=IE=G=I and F=H=JF=H=JF=H=J, and B(B(x,w),v)=B(x,C(v,w))B(B(x, w), v) = B(x, C(v, w))B(B(x,w),v)=B(x,C(v,w)) written normally is just vâ‹…(wâ‹…x)=vwâ‹…xv \cdot (w \cdot x) = vw \cdot xvâ‹…(wâ‹…x)=vwâ‹…x.

  • In many cases we need to construct an indicator simple process of an elementary predictable set (in fact, all explicitly defined simple processes are defined as this). This requires 1:F1 : F1:F. In all proofs such as Lemma 10.14 or the upcrossing lemmas where an explicit simple process is constructed, we use some sum of 1A1(s,t]\mathbb{1}_A\mathbb{1}_{(s,t]}1Aâ€‹1(s,t]â€‹ where AâˆˆFsA \in \mathcal{F}_{s}AâˆˆFsâ€‹. Integrating this indicator 1A1(s,t]âˆ™X=1A(Xtâˆ’Xs)\mathbb{1}_A\mathbb{1}_{(s,t]} \bullet X = \mathbb{1}_A(X^t - X^s)1Aâ€‹1(s,t]â€‹âˆ™X=1Aâ€‹(Xtâˆ’Xs) = A.indicator (X^t - X^s) then requires B(x,1)=xB(x, 1) = xB(x,1)=x.

In light of the above, the relationship between EEE and FFF is much more like vector/scalar fields rather than two vector fields, and BBB and âˆ™\bulletâˆ™ seem much more like scalar multiplications than bilinear maps (in fact, we would have Module (SimpleProcess F ğ“•) (Î¹ â†’ Î© â†’ E) with âˆ™\bulletâˆ™ as smul if not for the fact that 1 is not a simple process for infinite Î¹). Observe that the above bullet points are precisely the module axioms for Module F E, if we interpret BBB to be smul and CCC to be mul. So I think it is more appropriate to do this: E=GE = GE=G must be a module over FFF. FFF can be a normed algebra over R\mathbb{R}R. We probably also need IsScalarTower â„ F E if it is not inferred. I tried this at https://github.com/RemyDegenne/brownian-motion/pull/307 and it seems to work well.

I discussed this in DM with @RÃ©my Degenne and he agreed with the change, but suggested to ask publicly in this channel. I would like to see what everyone thinks before I proceed.

I agree that a general bilinear map seems overkill. However I think we still want to take into account something more general, your bullet points seem to match the case where F is a vector space and E is the space of operators over F I think? I think it would be nice to at least cover the case where F is Rn\mathbb R^nRn and E is the space of nÃ—nn \times nnÃ—n matrices, as this often appears in stochastic calculus. We should be able to deduce it from the E=F=RE = F = \mathbb RE=F=R case but this would surely involve a lot of duplication.
Sorry, do you mean the other way around, with F space of operators over E? Because otherwise what is a definition of B:Eâ†’Fâ†’EB : E \to F \to EB:Eâ†’Fâ†’E?
Yes probably I mixed up letters within your message. I mean B:Fâ†’L(F,F)â†’FB : F \to \mathcal L(F, F) \to FB:Fâ†’L(F,F)â†’F defined by B(x,f)=f(x)B(x, f) = f(x)B(x,f)=f(x).

I think mathematically that is covered by my proposed definition, because (in your notation) L(F,F)\mathcal{L}(F,F)L(F,F) is a normed algebra over R\mathbb{R}R, and FFF is a L(F,F)\mathcal{L}(F,F)L(F,F)-module, which is the generality I propose. (And in my above notation that would be EEE is a F=L(E,E)F=\mathcal{L}(E,E)F=L(E,E)-module, just to avoid confusion.)

I just thought about it more, and I think maybe this could also make sense: in Vâˆ™XV \bullet XVâˆ™X, VVV is L(E,G)\mathcal{L}(E, G)L(E,G)-valued (where GGG is another space) and XXX is EEE-valued. This is more general because it allows for the case where VVV is mÃ—nm\times nmÃ—n matrix where mâ‰ nm \ne nmî€ =n and XXX is Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn (which is considered in e.g. in Pascucci). The formula that was written Vâˆ™(Wâˆ™X)=(Vâ‹…W)âˆ™XV\bullet(W\bullet X)=(V\cdot W)\bullet XVâˆ™(Wâˆ™X)=(Vâ‹…W)âˆ™X is now actually (Vâˆ˜W)âˆ™X(V\circ W)\bullet X(Vâˆ˜W)âˆ™X where âˆ˜\circâˆ˜ is composition. Where indicators are needed, we require E=GE=GE=G.

Oh right we definitely want to cover the case of V being linear-map valued (which was my first def before Etienne told me we could generalize). I forgot about it when replying to your DM about restricting to the scalar multiplication.
(these slides use that definition with a linear map for example https://www.stoch-ana-hermite-sobolev.uni-freiburg.de/Tappe-Introduction-to-Stochastic-20210625.pdf, sorry for not having a better ref)
Yes we definitely want the case where the matrix is not a square too!
The slides make total sense, I regret not seeing them before!

I have only seen the matrix stochastic integral definition as a wrapper around the case where everything is scalar, which would be derived from elementary stochastic integral where VVV is scalar, but it seems we can go directly to the general stochastic integral, from a general elementary stochastic integral?

Yes, that's the way Tappe does it in those slides: start from a general elementary stochastic integral with VVV taking values in L(E,G)L(E, G)L(E,G), and prove the ItÃ´ isometry in that setting (I found those slides when looking for the "right generality" for the isometry).
Sorry again for being misleading with my answer in DM earlier. It's the week-end and I don't have a lot of time to think about those questions.
No worries! I or someone else should also modify the quadratic (co)variation and Ito isometry parts of the blueprint to generalize to something more like Tappe's slides.

Thomas Zhu said:

Then if VVV is HHH-valued, and there is B2:Gâ†’Hâ†’IB_2 : G \to H \to IB2â€‹:Gâ†’Hâ†’I, the final Vâˆ™(Wâˆ™X)V \bullet (W \bullet X)Vâˆ™(Wâˆ™X) is III-valued. Then we need a â€œmultiplicationâ€ C:Hâ†’Fâ†’JC : H \to F \to JC:Hâ†’Fâ†’J, another B3:Eâ†’Jâ†’IB_3 : E \to J \to IB3â€‹:Eâ†’Jâ†’I, and a condition B2(B1(x,w),v)=B3(x,C(v,w))B_2(B_1(x, w), v) = B_3(x, C(v, w))B2â€‹(B1â€‹(x,w),v)=B3â€‹(x,C(v,w)). I think this is too complicated. For example, if we simply require that B1=B2B_1 = B_2B1â€‹=B2â€‹, then to make things type-check we already have E=G=IE=G=IE=G=I and F=H=JF=H=JF=H=J, and B(B(x,w),v)=B(x,C(v,w))B(B(x, w), v) = B(x, C(v, w))B(B(x,w),v)=B(x,C(v,w)) written normally is just vâ‹…(wâ‹…x)=vwâ‹…xv \cdot (w \cdot x) = vw \cdot xvâ‹…(wâ‹…x)=vwâ‹…x.

Just wanted to point out that this is what we do in docs#MeasureTheory.convolution_assoc. So it is a bit annoying to write and you obviously want to specialize it right away, but it's not that unreasonable.

Update: my PR 340 (now ready for review) still uses the general bilinear map BBB (as in the blueprint), and the exact most general form of associativity suggested above. I have specialized it for L(E,F)L(E,F)L(E,F)-valued simple processes but specializing to R\mathbb{R}R-valued simple process is a TODO.

/-- The most general case of associativity of the elementary stochastic integral. -/
theorem integral_assoc {Bâ‚ : E â†’L[â„] H â†’L[â„] I} {Bâ‚‚ : F â†’L[â„] G â†’L[â„] H} {Bâ‚ƒ : E â†’L[â„] F â†’L[â„] J}
    {Bâ‚„ : J â†’L[â„] G â†’L[â„] I} (hB : âˆ€ x y z, Bâ‚ x (Bâ‚‚ y z) = Bâ‚„ (Bâ‚ƒ x y) z)
    (V : SimpleProcess E ğ“•) (W : SimpleProcess F ğ“•) (X : Î¹ â†’ Î© â†’ G) :
    integral Bâ‚ V (integral Bâ‚‚ W X âˆ˜ WithTop.some) = integral Bâ‚„ (mapâ‚‚ Bâ‚ƒ V W) X

I merged the PR.
I have a question about an aspect of the definition of the elementary stochastic integral that predates this PR. It is currently defined as a stochastic process indexed by WithTop Î¹, while the original processes are indexed by Î¹. It makes it easy to talk about the integral over the whole index by using the value at top, but I worry that the fact that we are adding a WithTop will become inconvenient later. I don't have any example of where it could be bad for now: I just know that Î¹ vs WithTop Î¹ is a recurring design question in files about stochastic processes and that we should keep this choice in mind and be ready to reconsider if we encounter a difficulty.

Currently, for the properties of the elementary stochastic integral, it seems to be easy to prove whether using WithTop or not. So if there is something in the future that shows defining without WithTop makes more sense, there is no reason not to switch.
